Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Dobutamine vs Phenylephrine on Graft Flow in Cerebral Bypass Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised crossover trial was conducted at the University Medical Centre Utrecht from September 2018 to July 2019.

Participants.evidence: Ten adult patients undergoing cerebral bypass surgery were included.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive dobutamine to increase cardiac index or phenylephrine to increase mean arterial pressure (MAP).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess whether dobutamine administration results in greater graft perfusion than phenylephrine.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the absolute change in graft flow between the reference and intervention phases.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using sealed opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: the anaesthesiologist was blinded to graft flow measurements.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ten adult patients undergoing cerebral bypass surgery were included.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Graft flow increased with a median of 4.1 ml/min (IQR, 1.7–12.0) after dobutamine and 3.6 ml/min (IQR, 1.3–7.8) after phenylephrine (difference –0.6 ml/min; 95% CI, –14.5 to 5.3; P = 0.441).

Harms.evidence: One patient experienced a short episode of atrial arrhythmia during dobutamine administration, with no haemodynamic consequences.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The study was registered at the Netherlands Trial Register (NL7077).
